which Toogood ostensibly has been waiting. The sales manager
of the company said they would not be in production before
June, which can readily be interpreted to mean several months
later. Therefor, hope in Toogood*s machine gets less and less
as time goes on. Before we make a firm move I would suggest
contacting Mr. T once more—if no answer is forthcoming then
something else is called for.
It seems to me there are threepossibilities which present
themselves as alternative solutions:
a. Find some one else to build a duplicator.
b. Build it ourselves.
c. Buy a string of stock recorders.
I don’t know who would undertake the job of building a
machine for us, or whether anyone would for a price we could
pay. I feel reasonably certain that if the right people from
here could be partially relieved of their other duties for a
little time, that we could build the machine ourselves. It
is possible that we could get some help from Toogood. We would
get considerable help from 3M. It seems to me a real possibility.
If we decide on stock machines I recommend we not use Magnecords.
The care required in keeping three of them running like anything
in time together is fantastic.
It soon will be the first of the year. There will be some
time between the decision and the operation of the equipment.
I therefore feel that it is essential to make a decision on this
as soon as possible. We have been waiting since June. Before
we appear before the foundation let’s have something underway.
